```{r setup, include = FALSE}
knitr::opts_chunk$set(echo = FALSE)

library(irex10)
library(DT)           # for interactive tables
options(scipen = 9)   # discourage conversion of raw numbers to scientific notation.

# Remove several modebar buttons from interactive plots.
minimal <- function(g)
              config(g, displaylogo = FALSE,
                     modeBarButtonsToRemove = c("autoScale2d", "zoomIn2d", "zoomOut2d"))

# Table convenience function.
table <- function(data, options = list(dom = 'tB', autoWidth = TRUE, buttons = c('csv', 'pdf', 'print'),
                                       columnDefs = list(list(className = 'dt-center', targets='_all'))),
                  colnames = pretty.colnames(names(data)), extensions = 'Buttons', escape = FALSE, ...)
{
   rownames(data) <- seq(nrow(data)) 
   datatable(data, options, ..., extensions = extensions, escape = escape)
}
```

<DIV id="main" class="nist-main">

# IREX 10: Ongoing Evaluation of Iris Recognition

This page presents performance results for the *Identification track* of the Iris Exchange (IREX) 10 evaluation of iris recognition technology. Most flagship deployments of iris recognition operate in identification mode, providing services ranging from prison management, border security, expedited processing, and distribution of resources.  Administered at the Image Group's Biometrics Research Lab (BRL), developers submit their matching software for testing over sequestered iris data.  As an ongoing evaluation, developers may submit at any time. The results of this ongoing evaluation are presented below.

Useful links:
<UL>
 <LI>[IREX 10 Homepage](https://www.nist.gov/programs-projects/irex-10-identification-track)</LI>
 <LI>[IREX 10 FAQ](https://www.nist.gov/itl/iad/ig/irex-10-frequently-asked-questions )</LI>
 <LI>Subscribe to the [IREX mailing list](mailto:irex+subscribe) to stay apprised of all IREX related activities.</LI>
 <LI>Send comments and recommendations to irex@nist.gov</LI>
</UL> 

## Leaderboard

Core accuracy is assessed using the 4th pull from the [Operational Dataset](https://www.nist.gov/itl/iad/image-group/irex-datasets). This iris image dataset is sequestered, meaning the participants are not granted access to the images, thereby preventing overtraining or fine-tuning to the images contained within the dataset. OPS 4 images are sometimes characterized as "field collected", having been acquired in a variety of indoor and outdoor environments. In contrast, datastets collected in more controlled university settings tend to suffer less from quality related problems (e.g. motion and focus blur).

<CENTER style="font-size:15px">
```{r Leaderboard}
test <- 'ops4/1eye/first'
FPIR <- 1e-2

# Restrict to current test and DETs that exist.
data <- irex10[test == .GlobalEnv$test & DET.exists(test, matcher)][,test := NULL]

# Estimate FNIR confidence interval for each matcher.
data <- data[, with( wilson.interval(test, matcher, FPIR),
                     .(FNIR = pretty(FNIR, (upper - lower) / 2) ) ),
               by = .(participant, submission.date)]

# -GW when results are available, replace creation and search time with new results

# Get template creation statistics.
data <- data[, with( get.template.stats(test, participant),
                     .(creation.time   = pretty(creation.time), 
                       num.bytes       = pretty(num.bytes),
                       submission.date = pretty(submission.date)))
             , by = .(participant, FNIR)]

# Get search statistics.
data[, search.time := pretty( get.search.stats(test, participant)$search ), by = names(data)]

# Set row order.
setorder(data, FNIR)

# Set column order.
cols <- c('participant', 'FNIR', 'search.time', 'num.bytes', 'creation.time', 'submission.date')
setcolorder(data, cols)

# Make column names more human friendly.
pretty.colnames(data)

# Display table.
table(data, width = 1050)

# Set test case variables for later reference.
size <- round( get.database.size(test) / 1e3 )
size <- ifelse(size >= 1e3, sprintf('%dM', size / 1e3), sprintf('%dK', size))

eyes <- ifelse(get.num.eyes(test) == 1, 'One eye', 'Both eyes')

enrollment.mode <- ifelse( grepl('first', test), 'One enrollment session', 'All enrollment sessions')
```
</CENTER>

<CENTER>
```{r CMC}

test  <- 'ops4/1eye/first'
ranks <- 10^(0:2)

# Restrict to test of interest.
data <- irex10[test == .GlobalEnv$test][,test := NULL]

# Load CMCs that exist.
data <- data[CMC.exists(test, matcher), load.CMC(test, participant),
               by = .(participant, submission.date)]

# Restrict to ranks of interest.
data <- data[rank %in% ranks]

data[,miss.rate := round(miss.rate, 3)]

# Restructure table data.
data <- dcast(data, participant + submission.date ~ rank, value.var = 'miss.rate')

# Sort rows by rank 1 miss rate.
setorder(data, 1)

# Rename and reorder columns.
cols <- c('Participant', sprintf('Rank %d Miss Rate', ranks), 'Submission Date')

setnames(data, c('participant', ranks, 'submission.date'), cols)
setcolorder(data, cols)

# Display table.
table(data, width = 900)
```
</CENTER>


There are three frames in the browser: 
<p>
</p><ol>
<li><strong>Test Cases</strong> (five CTC and six FTC) contain 421 PMI Annotations.  FTC 7, 10, and 11 were not modeled in any CAD system as part of the project.  
</li><li><strong>Annotation Type</strong> classifies PMI Annotation by dimensions, geometric tolerances, datum features, and datum targets.  Dimensions are split into
three categories including dimensions related to holes (counterbore, countersink, depth) and other dimensions (radius, slope, taper, slot).
</li><li><strong>PMI Annotations</strong> with multi-line feature control frames (FCF) are displayed on one line.  A "|" delimits the sections of a FCF.  
A "/" delimits mulitple lines of a FCF.  Tolerance zone and datum reference frame modifiers such as a maximum material modifier (letter M in a circle)
appear as the letter bracketed by parentheses, e.g., (M).  Tolerances or dimensions with “(Oriented)” after the FCF means that the tolerance or dimension 
has a specific orientation in a test case drawing.  Other modifiers similar modifiers are: Origin, All Around, and UOS.  UOS means “Unless Otherwise Specified” and
is usually associated with an overall surface profile in the notes.        
</li></ol>


## Speed

Times are measured as the the elapsed real time (i.e., "wall clock") as opposed to CPU time. Timing estimates were computed on unloaded machines with only a single process dedicated to biometric operations. The test machines are
<A href="https://www.dell.com/downloads/global/products/pedge/M910_Spec_Sheet.pdf">Dell PowerEdge M910</A> blades with Dual Intel Xeon X7560 2.3 GHz CPUs (eight cores per processor).
